title: Are there any countries that are completely self-sufficient? - Quora

response.answer_text: Feel free to correct me if you have more solid information. While there might be some smaller island nations or otherwise isolated countries that may be more self-sufficient %-wise, by necessity or choice, my guess is Russia. Based mainly on having a long history of operating in this waynatural resources potential of Russia is over 20% of the world’s reserves. ... Natural resources used by the economy of Russia account for 95.7% of national wealth. There are large deposits of fuel and energy resources: oil, natural gas, coal and uranium ore. … In addition, metal ores are mined on the country’s territory ores: iron, nickel, copper, aluminum, tin, polymetals, chromium, tungsten, gold, and silver. There is a great variety of non-metallic ores: phosphates, apatites, talc, asbestos, mica, potash and salt, diamonds, amber, precious and semiprecious stones. Very common are construction materials: sand, clay, limestone, marble, granite and other materials.  In 2005 Russia was the richest country in gold reserves. On the territory of Russia is 1/4 of the world's reserves of wood. (Wikipedia)Russia accounts for 1/4 of the world's production of fresh and frozen fish… (This and below statements are from other sources. I haven’t linked them because they might me slightly outdated.)[For an approximate understanding,] 9 % of the world’s agricultural land is located in Russia. Russia possesses 1/5 of the world’s fresh water reserve.politics, trade sanctionsIf it’s not, it probably could be.

I believe self-sufficiency is essentially the ready availability of critical resources, without excessive reliance on the outside world. I vote for Russia. It has: abundant mineral and energy resources: a whole lot of oil, natural gas, coal, metals (gold, uranium, iron, nickel, copper, tin, aluminum etc.), diamonds, rare earths. You name it, they probably have it over there.a huge agricultural potential that’s fueled by vast reserves of land and fresh water and can sustain both grain cultivation and animal husbandry.25% of all the world’s wood reserves (Forestry in Russia - Wikipedia).a population of over 140 million people, ready to provide the needed workforce in all sectors of the economy.a very good system of education, ranked 13th in the world, especially excelling in technical areas (Education in Russia - Wikipedia), coupled with a strong technological base.a government debt-to-GDP ratio of just 17.7%. That’s the second lowest in Europe after Estonia (Kosovo would also rank higher, but that’s not really a country). A prudent limit for developed countries is thought to be 60%. The USA stand at a whopping 104.17% (Country List Government Debt to GDP).And last but not least, Russia also has the military power to ensure that what’s theirs stays theirs (and maybe what’s other’s becomes theirs as well).

Not possible in today's world. Very difficult as it has to rely on trade with other nations to stay in a good economic state. Even if the country has enough resources , for good harmony it has to be a player in the international arena and there has to be a cordial relationship with other countries to ensure world peace. If the Arab nations don't share oil with other nations, the economy of other countries may collapse. Colonisation of most Asian countries happened mainly for search of natural resources. If such a scenario arises- where a country is self reliant, it will be either invaded or colonised. Very rare to find such a country in the world.

Self sufficiency is a mirage. No nation is truly self sufficient. Everyone needs something from the other. Oil producing nations need food and everything elese from outside. Food producing nations need oil and machinery from others. Machinery production is concentrated in a few nations only. This is the reason we have global eco system and globalization became a success.

What is the most self sufficient country? Hard to answer with complete certainty, because the standard of living is so different around the world. I like looking at this website: Dollar Street to see some of those differences. Numerically, you can assume that the country that imports the least as being the most self sufficient. In countries with very low imports, there could be a lot of things not available though. But here is a comparison based on that standard:  As you would expect, small island or landlocked nations are the most dependent, based on imports.

There are a couple of answers here that say Russia and they have some good points. But, my question to that is , what does all that do for their people? Their standard of living is ok but are they making the best use of their self sufficiency? I would look to either the United States or Canada. Both countries have a lot of natural resources and both countries have used their assets of agriculture, oil, natural gas, timber, minerals, fresh water, temperate climate with warm water ports and an educated citizenship to full advantage.

Maybe Norway, they have oil, and the ability to refine it. They can also produce food in large quantities to feed their people unlike most of the other oil rich places, the only other possible place might be Russia, but the lack the ability for large scale tech manufacturing to provide for their people, while Norway has a smaller population and thus wouldn’t need it to be so large scale. However due to the current global economy, it is unlikely that you will ever find a completely independent nation that can provide for itself.

I’m amazed that the most obvious answer did not come up yet! For a country to be fully self sufficient, the following criteria should be met:- Sufficient and stable food production to cover all needs (not necessarily peculiar wants) of the population;- Sufficient and stable energy production - with diversified energy sources (hydrocarbons, hydro, nuclear and renewables);- Strong and well supplied military, to resist any other, not fully self-sufficient countries’ attempts to take away the resources. Iran would probably e a good candidate for a high degree of self sufficiency as the restrictions placed upon them have forced them to rely upon their own resources. The have a high degree of self sufficiency with regards to food as well. There are of course limitations, especially on high tech products, with regards to such items as cell phones, computer hard and software, automobiles, etc. But by and large they have been forced into a high degree of self sufficiency.

The USA, by a VERY wide margin.---It is the only country able to do ALL of the following:- Oil itself- Feed itself- Teach itself- Water itself- Defend itself- Send ships to the Seven seas- Have most mineral ressources in country- Being able to produce almost all necessary technology in country- And has, the present tragicomedy in DC notwithstanding, a stable political system.

Yes but at a huge cost. It could not make the best cars, the best food, the best pharmaceuticals etc…there would be some compromise on quality. And that compromise gets larger the smaller the nation is. A small nation will not have all the minerals, oil, quality soil, human skills and weather to meet the market demand. But temper the demand for what it can produce then it's shaped to be self reliant. This is not a priority of any economy as far as I know.

A far off Pacific Island where there is no politics, no police, no churches serving up guilt and shame for everything that is pleasurable, no help but people helping each other, while running naked and living off the surrounding vegetation… The instant all that other stuff comes into play, the society will go dark, the people will turn to alcoholics because there is no longer any reason to live, and society will die…

Basically, in this world nobody is self-reliant and everyone is dependent on others help for survival. Even Lord Rama also requires the help of Sugreev to defeat Ravana. However, it is possible as one can live in a close compartment years together if we provided air, water and food. Similarly, a country can survive, but without using other support it is not possible to become strong and developed or maintain it. In such a situation, it is possible that who is stronger can invade us economically or politically and exploit us to become more powerful by fulfilling our minimum requirements.

The only thing you need is agriculture - as long as you’re having enough land and good ground you can do it. However the problem is that your diet won’t be rich, so you’ll start trading anyways, not even countries in the ancient or dark times were fully self sufficient. Plus you’d also want to have some medicine, something for your kids, maybe a better structure or your house, probably a car (oil from the Middle East, metals maybe from Asia or South America, German Engineering,…). You could be self sufficient but it wouldn’t be too nice.

Even US isn't self-sufficient (coming from a neutral perspective). US has one of the most abundant natural resources, high purchasing power, relatively affordable housing (compare to Asia), and solid legal structure. But even so, US isn't self-sufficient. If you look all the countries from the abundance of natural resources, almost none come closes to US. Bear in mind, I am not advocating for US supremacy. I am analyzing the question from a logical perspective.

As we progress more and more as a global society , no it is very difficult for any country to survive on its own. It may be possible if they try for it but it is not worth. Scientific research is the main area I would say which needed a lot of international cooperation. Research is a very expensive and time consuming process , especially in the health and life sciences. International cooperation is very common among scientist to avoid reinventing of wheels and speed up their path.

No. But many easily could be depending on what amount of consumer goods, much of it trash but some nice and some useful products they want to give up. 5 purses? Alexa? 3 flat screens, two cars, one car, Keurig coffee dingus, 30 shirts, 2,3, 4 watches, meat every day, eating out often, lower temp in house in winter, no AC in summer, less goods of all kinds in stores, no out of season fruits or vegetables and on and on

I think it would depend on what you consider self-sufficient. The U.S. has an extensive highway system which is very necessary for normal day to day things. That could easily not be the case in some smaller countries. Some poorer countries don’t have much of an electrical grid, but people still live there, here in the U.S. a loss of power even for a short time can have disastrous effects. I don’t think you’ll find any country that’s totally self-sufficient.

Of course but… People trade for mutual benefit, and what is good for a few neighbors is good for a neighborhood, and a state and a nation and the world. Trade allows for specialization, in terms of one’s skills/knowledge and tools. A person can be more efficient at that one thing than he could be trying to manage everything for himself. Trade enables efficient production by people specializing. A country can surely be self sufficient, most were not that long ago, but its better for countries to specialize just as it is the individual.

Iran is a good example. Being a self sufficient country is easy. However, in all cases it is better for the citizens to be able to conduct trade with other geographical areas where conditions and specialization favor more efficient production of certain goods than that at home.

None. North Korea’s policy of Juche aims at self suficiency (autarky) but of course they still trade with China and many other States around the world. Many countries are self sufficient in one or more commodities and export the surplus …
Iran comes close. With all the embargoes on it, it makes everything from toothpicks to nuclear sticks. On a more serious note,  except for oil , India is the closest you can get.
Probably Russia, which is very rich in critical natural resources of iron, coal, wood, etc.

Apparently Russia is. Besides the natural resources, Russia doesn’t need million of illegal immigrants to provide diversity and do menial jobs Russian workers refuse to do. Since Russia doesn’t need all that outside help, my vote goes to Russia.
USA is is most self-sustainable country in the world mostly having the all essential resources and the stable economically .

It would be a country with a lot of land over multiple climate types, many resources and people. China, America and Russia are the names that come to mind. Although Brazil, Argentina, India, and Australia must also be considered.
